entries.title: Ellis Island
entries.imageAlt: Image of a red brick building in Ellis Island.
entries.description: Would be such a fun day trip! You take a ferry there (best to book in advance). The Ellis Island National Museum of Immigration shares the stories of immigrants entering the U.S., and you also get a great view of the Statue of Liberty from the grounds.

entries.title: Brooklyn Army Terminal
entries.imageAlt: Image of an industrial looking builting with a tall open glass roof.
entries.description: You can enjoy a historic atrium, visit the waterfront, attend an event, or visit some local businesses. Would be a fun place for a mini photoshoot, and just explore somewhere new for a day!

entries.title: Brooklyn Botanic Garden
entries.imageAlt: Image of a greenhouse in Brooklyn Botanic Garden.
entries.description: Free for Pratt students with your ID! A peaceful escape with thousands of plant species spread over 52 acres, right beside Prospect Park. Especially beautiful during cherry blossom season.

entries.title: Pier 57
entries.imageAlt: Image of a Pier 57, with many structures seeming to sprout out from the water. There are trees lining these structures.
entries.description: A lively waterfront destination with a food hall, community events, and rooftop park space. Great for exploring art, culture, and nature. It's also right by the High Line, Little Island, and the Whitney Museum!

entries.title: Gantry Park LIC
entries.imageAlt: Image of Gantry Park, aerial view. There is water, trees, and a playground area.
entries.imageCredit: New York State Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation
entries.description: I hear this is a great spot to catch a sunset of the Manhattan skyline, including landmarks like the Empire State Building and the United Nations. There are lawns, piers, and recreational facilities - perfect for relaxing or joining a casual sports drop-in.

entries.title: Prospect Park
entries.imageAlt: Image of a park, with a winding path, people and dogs, and lots of trees.
entries.description: You can play sports and touch grass. I love how the website curated a whole list of things to do, including volleyball (my favourite sport!). Seems like a peaceful place to do enjoy a book outside, have a picnic with friends, or stroll with family.

entries.title: Roosevelt Island
entries.imageAlt: Image of Roosevelt Island, with a focus on the lighthouse.
entries.description: A quick day trip with unique views of Manhattan from the aerial tramway! There are parks, walking trails, and the historic lighthouse at the northern tip. NYC Tourism created a list of things to do. It's not too far from Manhattan, either.

entries.title: Governor's Island
entries.imageAlt: Image of a man exploring a park, walking on rocks, with a view of the cityscape and water.
entries.description: A car-free island! This calls for a daytrip - I want to bike around, see monuments, and view public art. They also have a very long slide you can go down, but I'm a little scared of slides. Anywho, to get there, you can hop on a free ferry! The official website has a list of things to do.

entries.title: Forest Hill Gardens
entries.imageAlt: Image of a red house surrounded by greenery and a paving road.
entries.description: A picturesque neighbourhood in Queens - it sort of feels like you're walking around in the UK because they have so much Tudor Revival architecture. Great for a leisurely stroll, admiring the gardens and tree-lined streets.

entries.title: New York Botanical Garden
entries.imageAlt: Image of a greenhouse on a blue-sky day. There are lilypads in the foreground and lots of greenery.
entries.description: A massive botanical oasis in the Bronx - the flagship garden of NYC. Features rare and exotic plants, special exhibits, and even a preserved old-growth forest. Worth checking the calendar for seasonal events.

entries.title: Riverdale
entries.imageAlt: Image of two houses, where you can see the river.
entries.description: The name reminds me of the show Riverdale I used to love in high school. Anyway, the real Riverdale is a quiet, residential neighborhood in the Bronx with stunning views of the Hudson River. I'd love to explore the beautiful architecture there - especially the Colonial Revival, Tudor Revival, and Beaux-Arts homes!
